lessons.title: Caesar Cipher - Introduction
lessons.description: Learn the fundamentals of Caesar cipher encryption
lessons.content:
The Caesar Cipher is one of the simplest and most widely known encryption techniques. It is a type of substitution cipher in which each letter in the plaintext is replaced by a letter some fixed number of positions down the alphabet.

For example, with a shift of 3:
â€¢ A becomes D
â€¢ B becomes E
â€¢ C becomes F

This cipher is named after Julius Caesar, who used it to communicate with his generals. While it's not secure by modern standards, it's an excellent introduction to cryptographic concepts.

Key Concepts:
â€¢ Plaintext: The original message
â€¢ Ciphertext: The encrypted message
â€¢ Key (Shift): The number of positions to shift
â€¢ Encryption: Converting plaintext to ciphertext
â€¢ Decryption: Converting ciphertext back to plaintext

lessons.title: Variables and Data Types
lessons.description: Understanding how to store and manipulate data
lessons.content:
Variables are containers for storing data values. In programming, we use different data types to represent different kinds of information.

Common Data Types:
â€¢ Integer: Whole numbers (e.g., 42, -7, 0)
â€¢ Float/Double: Decimal numbers (e.g., 3.14, -0.5)
â€¢ String: Text (e.g., "Hello", "World")
â€¢ Boolean: True or False values

Variables allow us to:
â€¢ Store data temporarily
â€¢ Reuse values throughout our code
â€¢ Make our programs dynamic and flexible

Best Practices:
â€¢ Use meaningful variable names
â€¢ Choose appropriate data types
â€¢ Initialize variables before use
â€¢ Follow naming conventions
